docs.lead_paragraph: Experts expressed frustration that efforts to reform the health care system so rarely relied on rigorous methods of evaluation like the one known as random assignment.

headline.main: Few Health System Studies Use Top Method, Report Says
headline.print_headline: Few Health System Studies Use Top Method, Report Says

docs.abstract: Study published in journal Science finds that majority of scientific research conducted to improve the American health care system does not utilize random assignment, methodology that is considered gold standard; finds only 18 percent of such research used the rigorous approach of random assignment in treatment trials.
docs.snippet: Experts expressed frustration that efforts to reform the health care system so rarely relied on rigorous methods of evaluation like the one known as random assignment.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dietary advice can be confusing. Is it OK to eat meat and eggs? Is fat in or out? What about grains? How much salt?

headline.main: Your Letters: Supplement Standards, New Teeth and Bingo

docs.lead_paragraph: Getting vaccinated is not a “personal choice.” It’s a public health duty and civic obligation.
docs.abstract: Nicholas Kristof Op-Ed column criticizes American politicians like Sen Rand Paul and New Jersey Gov Chris Christie, in wake of measles outbreak, for irresponsibly suggesting that vaccinations may be dangerous; notes that such health illiteracy is bipartisan; underscores effectiveness of vaccination, and suggests that it is every healthy citizen's responsibility to be vaccinated.
docs.snippet: Getting vaccinated is not a “personal choice.” It’s a public health duty and civic obligation.

docs.lead_paragraph: To avoid “he-said, she-said” vaccine coverage, it’s important to clearly state the settled science.
docs.abstract: Margaret Sullivan The Public Editor column assesses coverage by The New York Times of measles outbreak, particularly coverage of those who do not believe in vaccines.
docs.snippet: To avoid “he-said, she-said” vaccine coverage, it’s important to clearly state the settled science.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama is right to push a personalized approach to health care forward, though high costs remain a concern.
docs.abstract: Editorial praises proposal contained in Pres Obama's budget that promotes practice of 'personalized medicine,' also known as 'precision medicine'; notes that while practice may not live up to hype of curing diseases that are currently incurable, increasing funding for personalized medicine could revolutionize care and would almost certainly result in best quality of care.
docs.snippet: President Obama is right to push a personalized approach to health care forward, though high costs remain a concern.
